sections.summary: Zechariah appeals to Allah in seclusion for an heir to inherit the House of Jacob despite his advanced age and his wife's sterility. Allah grants him **John (Yahya)**, a prophet characterized by **wisdom**, **tenderness**, and **devotion**, as a sign of divine omnipotence [417–418].

Mary conceives **Jesus (Isa)** through divine intervention and faces her people with a miraculous infant who speaks from the crib to declare his status as a **servant of Allah** and a **prophet**. The text affirms Jesus as the **Word of truth** and clarifies that it is not fitting for Allah to have a child, as He only decrees "**Be**" for any matter [418–419].

Abraham, a man of truth and a **prophet**, invites his father to abandon **idolatry** and the service of the devil in favor of divine knowledge. After facing rejection and threats, he withdraws from his community and is blessed with the prophetic lineage of **Isaac** and **Jacob** [419–420].

Allah details the selection of prophets including **Moses**, **Aaron**, **Ishmael**, and **Idris**, highlighting their shared heritage and commitment to **prayer** and **charity**. These chosen individuals represent the succession of divine favor upon the descendants of **Adam** and **Noah** [420–421].

A warning is issued against subsequent generations who neglected **prayer** and followed their desires, contrasting their fate with the **repentant** who are promised the **Gardens of Eden**. Allah is identified as the Lord of the heavens and the earth, demanding steadfastness in His **worship**.

The text refutes human skepticism regarding the **Resurrection**, affirming that the Creator who originated humanity will round up the defiant for judgment. While the **devout** are eventually rescued, the **wrongdoers** are left in Hell on their knees [421–422].

Disbelievers who pride themselves on **influence** and material wealth are reminded that Allah increases guidance for the **righteous** whose deeds endure. The text warns that false gods will become opponents to their worshipers on the Day the **righteous** are gathered as honored guests [422–423].

A severe rebuke is given to those who attribute a **son** to the Most Merciful, a claim so monstrous it nearly causes the heavens to rupture. The surah concludes by affirming that every being in existence enters the divine presence as a **servant**, promising **love** for those who believe and work righteousness.
